Common defines for GPIO_FLAGS parameter

#define GPIO_BOTHEDGES   (3 << 7)
 Sense Both Edges.
#define GPIO_BUSKEEPER   (3 << 2)
 Bus Keeper.
#define GPIO_DIR_INPUT   (0 << 0)
 Pin is Input.
#define GPIO_DIR_OUTPUT   (1 << 0)
 Pin is Output.
#define GPIO_DRIVE_HIGH   (2 << 4)
 Drive High Configuration.
#define GPIO_DRIVE_LOW   (1 << 4)
 Drive Low Configuration.
#define GPIO_DRIVE_MAX   (3 << 4)
 Drive Max Configuration.
#define GPIO_DRIVE_MIN   (0 << 4)
 Drive Min Configuration.
#define GPIO_FALLING   (7 << 7)
 Sense Falling Edge.
#define GPIO_INIT_HIGH   (1 << 1)
 Initial Ouptput State is High.
#define GPIO_INIT_LOW   (0 << 1)
 Initial Ouptput State is Low.
#define GPIO_INTERRUPT   (1 << 7)
 Enable Pin/Group Interrupt.
#define GPIO_OPEN_DRAIN   (1 << 6)
 Open-Drain (when output).
#define GPIO_PULL_DOWN   (2 << 2)
 Pull-Down (when input).
#define GPIO_PULL_UP   (1 << 2)
 Pull-Up (when input).
#define GPIO_RISING   (5 << 7)
 Sense Risign Edge.
Interrupt Trigger Modes

#define GPIO_FALLING_EDGE   2
 Interrupt triggered upon falling edge.
#define GPIO_PIN_CHANGE   0
 Interrupt triggered upon pin change.
#define GPIO_RISING_EDGE   1
 Interrupt triggered upon rising edge.
Return Values of the GPIO API

#define GPIO_INVALID_ARGUMENT   1
 Input parameters are out of range.
#define GPIO_SUCCESS   0
 Function successfully completed.

Peripheral Bus Interface

Low-speed interface with a non-deterministic number of clock cycles per access.

This interface operates with lower clock frequencies (fPB <= fCPU), and its timing is not deterministic since it needs to access a shared bus which may be heavily loaded.

Note:
This interface is immediately available without initialization.

Detailed Description

GPIO software driver interface for AVR UC3.

  • Compiler: GCC and IAR for AVR
  • Supported devices: All AVR UC3 devices with a GPIO module can be used.
  • AppNote:
Author:
Atmel Corporation: http://www.atmel.com
Support and FAQ: http://support.atmel.no/

00402             gpio_port->oderc = mask;
00403     }
00404

Here is the call graph for this function:

void gpio_enable_gpio_pin ( uint32_t  pin  ) 

Enables the GPIO mode of a pin.

Parameters:
pin The pin number.
Refer to the product header file `uc3x.h' (where x is the part number; e.g. x = a0512) for pin definitions. E.g., to enable the GPIO mode of PX21, AVR32_PIN_PX21 can be used. Module pins such as AVR32_PWM_3_PIN for PWM channel 3 can also be used to release module pins for GPIO.

Definition at line 160 of file gpio.c.

00165 }

Here is the call graph for this function:

int gpio_enable_module_pin ( uint32_t  pin,
uint32_t  function 
)

Enables a specific module mode for a pin.

Parameters:
pin The pin number.
Refer to the product header file `uc3x.h' (where x is the part number; e.g. x = a0512) for module pins. E.g., to enable a PWM channel output, the pin number can be AVR32_PWM_3_PIN for PWM channel 3.
function The pin function.
Refer to the product header file `uc3x.h' (where x is the part number; e.g. x = a0512) for module pin functions. E.g., to enable a PWM channel output, the pin function can be AVR32_PWM_3_FUNCTION for PWM channel 3.
Returns:
GPIO_SUCCESS or GPIO_INVALID_ARGUMENT.

00098 #if defined(AVR32_GPIO_210_H_INCLUDED) || defined(AVR32_GPIO_211_H_INCLUDED) || defined(AVR32_GPIO_212_H_INCLUDED)
00099     gpio_port->pmr2c = 1 << (pin & 0x1F);
00100 #endif
00101     break;
00102 
00103   case 3: // D function.
00104     gpio_port->pmr0s = 1 << (pin & 0x1F);
00105     gpio_port->pmr1s = 1 << (pin & 0x1F);
00106 #if defined(AVR32_GPIO_210_H_INCLUDED) || defined(AVR32_GPIO_211_H_INCLUDED) || defined(AVR32_GPIO_212_H_INCLUDED)
00107     gpio_port->pmr2c = 1 << (pin & 0x1F);
00108 #endif
00109     break;
00110 
00111 #if defined(AVR32_GPIO_210_H_INCLUDED) || defined(AVR32_GPIO_211_H_INCLUDED) || defined(AVR32_GPIO_212_H_INCLUDED)
00112   case 4: // E function.
00113     gpio_port->pmr0c = 1 << (pin & 0x1F);
00114     gpio_port->pmr1c = 1 << (pin & 0x1F);
00115     gpio_port->pmr2s = 1 << (pin & 0x1F);
00116     break;
00117     
00118   case 5: // F function.
00119     gpio_port->pmr0s = 1 << (pin & 0x1F);
00120     gpio_port->pmr1c = 1 << (pin & 0x1F);
00121     gpio_port->pmr2s = 1 << (pin & 0x1F);
00122     break;
00123     
00124   case 6: // G function.
00125     gpio_port->pmr0c = 1 << (pin & 0x1F);
00126     gpio_port->pmr1s = 1 << (pin & 0x1F);
00127     gpio_port->pmr2s = 1 << (pin & 0x1F);
00128     break;
00129     
00130   case 7: // H function.
00131     gpio_port->pmr0s = 1 << (pin & 0x1F);
00132     gpio_port->pmr1s = 1 << (pin & 0x1F);
00133     gpio_port->pmr2s = 1 << (pin & 0x1F);
00134     break;
00135 #endif
00136 
00137   default:
00138     return GPIO_INVALID_ARGUMENT;
00139   }
00140 
00141   // Disable GPIO control.
00142   gpio_port->gperc = 1 << (pin & 0x1F);
00143 
00144   return GPIO_SUCCESS;
00145 }

void gpio_enable_pin_glitch_filter ( uint32_t  pin  ) 

Enables the glitch filter of a pin.

When the glitch filter is enabled, a glitch with duration of less than 1 clock cycle is automatically rejected, while a pulse with duration of 2 clock cycles or more is accepted. For pulse durations between 1 clock cycle and 2 clock cycles, the pulse may or may not be taken into account, depending on the precise timing of its occurrence. Thus for a pulse to be guaranteed visible it must exceed 2 clock cycles, whereas for a glitch to be reliably filtered out, its duration must not exceed 1 clock cycle. The filter introduces 2 clock cycles latency.

Parameters:
pin The pin number.

Definition at line 520 of file gpio.c.

References GPIO.

00521 {
00522   volatile avr32_gpio_port_t *gpio_port = &GPIO.port[pin >> 5];
00523   gpio_port->gfers = 1 << (pin & 0x1F);
00524 }
